RssItem.Title: Trump Has Changed a Night at the Opera, Too
RssItem.Description: Political strands within familiar works have been popping out with startling resonance in a series of recent performances, our critic writes.

RssItem.Title: Shakira Finds Liberation, One Song at a Time
RssItem.Description: The songs in Spanish on this Colombian star’s new album, “El Dorado,” bring back her playfulness. The track “Chantaje” already has 1.5 billion streams.

RssItem.Title: The Saturday Profile: From Heavy Metal Frontman to Taiwan’s Parliament
RssItem.Description: Freddy Lim left the “Black Sabbath of Asia” to start the New Power Party, which mixes liberal politics with a nationalist soft spot for President Trump.

RssItem.Title: Playlist: The Playlist: Matt Ox Delivers the Sound of This Second
RssItem.Description: Hear the week's most notable new songs from Rita Ora, Washed Out, Gary Allan, Charles Lloyd and more.

RssItem.Title: Review: A Fast-Rising Czech Conductor Leads the Philharmonic
RssItem.Description: Jakub Hrusa, 35, performed works by Dvorak and Janacek at David Geffen Hall, including Dvorak’s Violin Concerto with Augustin Hadelich.

RssItem.Title: That Decisive Moment: Bluesy Incantation: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
RssItem.Description: The violinist Augustin Hadelich's virtuosic performance of Dvorak, and surprise in "Carmen" and Franz Schmidt's Symphony No. 2 were among the highlights.

RssItem.Title: Ariana Grande to Perform a Benefit Concert in Manchester
RssItem.Description: In a long note posted on her social media accounts, the pop singer offered condolences and thanked her fans for their compassion and support.

RssItem.Title: Popcast: Festivals That Inspire Awe, and Festivals That Lead to Criminal Investigations
RssItem.Description: Music fests are ubiquitous, but only some are curated well enough to be thrilling. And there’s the Fyre Festival. A panel discussion of the current festival climate, on Popcast.

RssItem.Title: Gregg Allman, Influential Force Behind the Allman Brothers Band, Dies at 69
RssItem.Description: The singer, keyboardist and songwriter was a founder of the Allman Brothers Band and a composer of songs like “Whipping Post” and “Midnight Rider.”

RssItem.Title: Listen to 10 Definitive Gregg Allman Songs
RssItem.Description: Gregg Allman, who died Saturday, stirred all of the mythic South into his music. Here’s a sampling, mostly recorded with the Allman Brothers Band.

RssItem.Title: Linkin Park Beats Expectations With 6th Chart-Topping Album
RssItem.Description: This band’s latest release, “One More Light,” debuted at No. 1. Kendrick Lamar’s “Damn.” is No. 2 and Harry Styles’s solo debut slipped to No. 3.

RssItem.Title: Inside Sonny Rollins’s Jazz Archive, Headed Home to Harlem
RssItem.Description: This personal collection of hundreds of Mr. Rollins’s recordings and notes reveal his quest to improve his stamina and power as a saxophonist.

RssItem.Title: Pharoah Sanders and Perfume Genius to Perform at Dutch Festival
RssItem.Description: Le Guess Who? festival, now in its 11th year, will take place in Utrecht on Nov. 9-12.

RssItem.Title: Skin Deep: Hilary Duff Is Still a Shimmering Star
RssItem.Description: The “Younger” actress talks about her love of masks, serums and anything shimmery.

RssItem.Title: Alanis Morissette Has Written a Musical Based on ‘Jagged Little Pill’
RssItem.Description: The new musical, with music and lyrics by Ms. Morissette and a book by Diablo Cody, is to be directed by Diane Paulus at the American Repertory Theater.

RssItem.Title: For the Vienna Philharmonic, Summer Means Schönbrunn
RssItem.Description: The globally popular outdoor concert at the palace will include Renée Fleming, “Harry Potter” film music and Christoph Eschenbach’s conducting.

RssItem.Title: Summer Reading: Hot Tracks: Summer’s Big Books on Rock, Pop, Soul and Jazz
RssItem.Description: From the Beatles and Wilson Pickett to Michael Nesmith and the Sex Pistols.

RssItem.Title: Ariana Grande Announces Manchester Benefit Concert, With Special Guests
RssItem.Description: Justin Bieber, Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus and Coldplay will join the pop singer at a show to raise money for the We Love Manchester Emergency Fund.

RssItem.Title: ‘Liar, Liar’: A Song Assailing Theresa May Tops the Charts in Britain
RssItem.Description: A scathing song that takes aim at the prime minister has climbed to the top of the British iTunes chart ahead of next week’s general election.

RssItem.Title: Critic's Notebook: Can Meredith Monk Teach a Musical State of Mind?
RssItem.Description: The ensemble M6, performing on Wednesday at Roulette in Brooklyn, revives Ms. Monk’s elusive early vocal works.

RssItem.Title: Alan Gilbert Made the New York Philharmonic ‘a Bigger Box’
RssItem.Description: As the music director prepares to leave after eight seasons, our critic says he has boldly expanded the orchestra’s mind-set.

RssItem.Title: Kennedy Center’s New Jazz Season Includes Q-Tip and Local Artists
RssItem.Description: Jason Moran will return as the artistic director for jazz, focusing on cross-disciplinary presentations and spotlighting the Washington jazz scene.

RssItem.Title: Dua Lipa Was Raised on Pop Bangers. Now She Writes Them.
RssItem.Description: Ms. Lipa’s sassy pop songs have been streamed hundreds of millions of times. Her debut album arrives this week.

RssItem.Title: Album Review: Halsey’s Second Album: Something New, but a Lot Borrowed
RssItem.Description: The release, “hopeless fountain kingdom,” is a conventional take on radio pop from a singer who seemed poised to stand in opposition to the mainstream.

RssItem.Title: David Lewiston, Who Recorded Indigenous Music Far and Wide, Dies at 88
RssItem.Description: No sound was alien to Mr. Lewiston, whose work on albums for the Nonesuch label took him from Indonesia to Tibet to Guatemala to Kashmir.

RssItem.Title: Northside Festival Adds Activism and Politics to the Music
RssItem.Description: As it has grown into Brooklyn’s version of SXSW, this festival has wrapped innovation into its sprawling schedule.

RssItem.Title: ‘Angels in America,’ the Opera, in New York
RssItem.Description: The Hungarian composer Peter Eotvos’s adaptation of Tony Kushner’s epic play had an acclaimed Paris premiere in 2004 and now it makes its New York debut.

RssItem.Title: Review: Esa-Pekka Salonen Brings Mahler to Carnegie, Ever So Coolly
RssItem.Description: Emphasizing this composer’s Nordic roots, Mr. Salonen led the Met Orchestra in a program focusing on Mahler, the first of three concerts.

RssItem.Title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

RssItem.Title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

RssItem.Title: From the Archives: The Original Review of ‘Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band’
RssItem.Description: This assessment of the Beatles’ album ran in The New York Times on June 18, 1967.

RssItem.Title: Jiri Belohlavek, Czech Conductor, Dies at 71
RssItem.Description: Mr. Belohlavek was an accomplished interpreter of his country’s leading composers, including Antonin Dvorak, Leos Janacek, Bohuslav Martinu and Josef Suk.

RssItem.Title: Fyre Was Bad. For the Concert Industry, This One Could Be Worse.
RssItem.Description: The failures of the Fyre and Pemberton music festivals are spurring worries about eroding consumer confidence and growing hurdles for smaller, independent festivals.

RssItem.Title: The Beatles’ ‘Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band’ at 50: Still Full of Joy and Whimsy
RssItem.Description: It’s time to free the album of its cultural burdens and enjoy the fun.

RssItem.Title: Alan Gilbert Wanted to Save the New York Philharmonic. What Happened?
RssItem.Description: As Mr. Gilbert prepares to step down as the orchestra’s music director, he finds his legacy is far from assured.

RssItem.Title: How the Fleet Foxes Frontman Got Out to Get Back In
RssItem.Description: Robin Pecknold, lead singer of the indie rock band, needed a six-year sabbatical before he could rejoin his band mates for their record “Crack-Up.”

RssItem.Title: Critic's Notebook: Thoreau: American Resister (and Kitten Rescuer)
RssItem.Description: A model of resistance for our time, Thoreau was not just the antisocial man of legend. He was a sensualist, his journal, a New York treasure, shows.

RssItem.Title: ‘The Leftovers’ Leads Television’s Musical Golden Age
RssItem.Description: On some of best series, the song selections are as nuanced, ironic and transcendent as the acting and writing.

RssItem.Title: The Woman Behind ‘Wonder Woman’
RssItem.Description: For the director Patty Jenkins, a world in crisis demands a heroine who is sincere.

RssItem.Title: Art Review: Columbia’s New Harlem Museum Opens, With Art From Its Neighbors
RssItem.Description: “Uptown” inaugurates the Wallach Art Gallery’s new home in a Renzo Piano building, the fraternal twin of the Whitney.

RssItem.Title: Art Review: Wild Waves and Quiet Streets: 2 Artists Working From Memory
RssItem.Description: Peder Balke and William Chappel, subjects of shows at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, were very different painters but had a surprising amount in common.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘Wonder Woman’ Is a Blockbuster That Lets Itself Have Fun
RssItem.Description: The movie, directed by Patty Jenkins and starring Gal Gadot, shakes off branding imperatives with touches of screwball comedy and romantic adventure.

RssItem.Title: Critic's Notebook: Still Reforming Postmodern Dance, California Roots Intact
RssItem.Description: Two dance programs and an exhibition celebrate women, specifically female reformers who challenge what postmodern dance can be.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘The Exception’ Is a Diverting Tale Set Before Nazi Horrors Fully Emerged
RssItem.Description: Christopher Plummer plays the exiled German Kaiser Wilhelm II in this melodrama, which unfolds in the Netherlands in the early years of the Second World War.

RssItem.Title: Chatter: 4 New Ways to Stream Great European TV
RssItem.Description: Here’s a quick look at the specialty streaming services AcornTV, BritBox, MHz Choice and Walter Presents, and the best shows they have on offer.

RssItem.Title: Jiri Belohlavek, Czech Conductor, Dies at 71
RssItem.Description: Mr. Belohlavek was an accomplished interpreter of his country’s leading composers, including Antonin Dvorak, Leos Janacek, Bohuslav Martinu and Josef Suk.

RssItem.Title: From the Archives: The Original Review of ‘Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band’
RssItem.Description: This assessment of the Beatles’ album ran in The New York Times on June 18, 1967.

RssItem.Title: American Beauties: ‘On Fire’ Makes Bad Habits Sound Very Sweet
RssItem.Description: This 1994 firefighting memoir, by the Southern writer Larry Brown, vividly captures both fear and the sort of pride that comes with mastery.

RssItem.Title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

RssItem.Title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to new art shows, and some that will be closing soon.

RssItem.Title: Works in Progress: Naked (and Very Close) in the Name of Art
RssItem.Description: Angelo Musco’s photographs are all about the human body. Actually, thousands of human bodies.

RssItem.Title: Film Series in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to film series and special screenings.

RssItem.Title: Dance in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to dance performances.

RssItem.Title: Comedy in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

RssItem.Title: This Weekend: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
RssItem.Description: Got an Hour? Got a bunch of hours? Let us be the soft glow of the TV set that lights your way in the dark.

RssItem.Title: Review: In ‘Past Life,’ Family Mysteries and Cosmic Questions
RssItem.Description: This film by the Israeli director Avi Nesher, based on Baruch Milch’s memoir, uses a potboiler setup to delve into themes of history and reconciliation.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘From the Ashes’ Sees Coal’s Dark Present and Dim Future
RssItem.Description: This documentary’s best moments come not from citing statistics or experts, but from talking with ordinary people affected by the coal industry.

RssItem.Title: What’s New in NYC Theater
RssItem.Description: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.

RssItem.Title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
RssItem.Description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

RssItem.Title: Streaming: ‘Midnight Return’ and ‘Becoming Bond’: The Smuggler and the Spy
RssItem.Description: “Midnight Return” is about an American’s harrowing prison sentence in Turkey in 1970 that inspired a film; “Becoming Bond” traces the life of George Lazenby, a one-time James Bond.

RssItem.Title: Review: Esa-Pekka Salonen Brings Mahler to Carnegie, Ever So Coolly
RssItem.Description: Emphasizing this composer’s Nordic roots, Mr. Salonen led the Met Orchestra in a program focusing on Mahler, the first of three concerts.

RssItem.Title: When the Grip Is a Woman (and the Gaffer and the Camera Operator, Too)
RssItem.Description: A few film directors are trying to change a persistent gender imbalance behind the camera by hiring female-majority crews. The process hasn’t always been smooth.

RssItem.Title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
RssItem.Description: New paintings by Patricia Treib and Eric Fischl; Mathias Poledna’s time-obsessed art; and an exhibition of works by imprisoned artists.

RssItem.Title: Show Us Your Wall: A Living Room Fit for a King
RssItem.Description: Bronson van Wyck, descended from one of the New York area’s Dutch founding families, enjoys decorating his home as he usually designs temporary spaces.

RssItem.Title: ‘Sense8’ Cancellation Is Netflix’s Second in a Week
RssItem.Description: The globe-trotting sci-fi drama from the Wachowski siblings made it to two seasons.

RssItem.Title: A New Tolkien Book Was Inspired by the Author’s Own Romance
RssItem.Description: The book, “Beren and Lúthien,” was compiled and edited by Christopher Tolkien, the third son of the author.

RssItem.Title: Review: High School Is Still Terrible for a ‘Handsome Devil’
RssItem.Description: Two unlikely friends at an all-boys school in Ireland must survive their classmates’ bullying with the help of a sympathetic teacher.

RssItem.Title: Review: Power Ballads as Couples Therapy in ‘Band Aid’
RssItem.Description: Zoe Lister-Jones wrote, directed and stars in this comedy about an out-of-sync couple turning their squabbles into songs.

RssItem.Title: Review: In ‘Vincent N Roxxy,’ Love Is in the Air, N So Is Fear
RssItem.Description: This combination crime drama and romance finds Emile Hirsch and Zoë Kravitz circling each other, and trying to stay away from bad guys.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘Tatara Samurai’ Forges a Man of Honor
RssItem.Description: This historical action movie from Yoshinari Nishikori has a laudably realistic grit and takes an unexpected turn for a film of its genre.

RssItem.Title: Review: A Powerful Newcomer Plays an Outcast in ‘Sami Blood’
RssItem.Description: A coming-of-age tale of an indigenous Sami girl, played by the expressive Lene Cecilia Sparrok, examines systemic discrimination in Sweden in the 1930s.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘Captain Underpants,’ Pretty Much What You’d Expect
RssItem.Description: DreamWorks brings the book series to the screen, riding the voices of Kevin Hart and Thomas Middleditch and a story featuring huge bathroom fixtures.

RssItem.Title: A Movie Poster Body-Shamed Snow White, and Chloë Grace Moretz Was ‘Appalled’
RssItem.Description: The actress stars in a computer-animated movie facing backlash for an ad suggesting the main character is “no longer beautiful” when overweight.

RssItem.Title: Frick Collection Expands Pay-What-You-Wish Hours
RssItem.Description: Museumgoers will be able to choose their admission price on Wednesdays from 2 to 6 p.m.

RssItem.Title: A New Play by Lynn Nottage, and More, Coming Soon to the Public Theater
RssItem.Description: Next season, the theater is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its home on Lafayette Street. Here are some highlights.

RssItem.Title: ‘Bill Nye: Science Guy’: Fighting for the Right to Use Facts
RssItem.Description: This new documentary, part of the Human Rights Watch Film Festival, sees the bow-tied educator taking on climate-change deniers with cold, hard facts.

RssItem.Title: ‘Marvin’s Room’ Makes Its Broadway Debut with Janeane Garofalo and Lili Taylor
RssItem.Description: Scott McPherson’s play, a deathbed comedy that premiered Off Broadway in 1991, is inextricable from his struggle with AIDS.

RssItem.Title: Alexander Calder at the Whitney: ‘Hypermobility’ and Shifting Perspectives
RssItem.Description: A new exhibition will put this artist’s kinetic works in front of audiences the way he intended: in motion.

RssItem.Title: ‘Angels in America,’ the Opera, in New York
RssItem.Description: The Hungarian composer Peter Eotvos’s adaptation of Tony Kushner’s epic play had an acclaimed Paris premiere in 2004 and now it makes its New York debut.

RssItem.Description: As it has grown into Brooklyn’s version of SXSW, this festival has wrapped innovation into its sprawling schedule.

RssItem.Title: Dance: The Choreographer Vicky Shick Explores Drama With the Body
RssItem.Description: Ms. Shick, one of the dance world’s local treasures, presents a full-length work that explores character as much as coordination.

RssItem.Title: ‘Aerial America’ Turns Its Bird’s Eye on New York
RssItem.Description: This Smithsonian Channel series records a day in the life of the metropolis, shot entirely from the air.

RssItem.Title: Devon Teuscher, a Poet in Ballet Shoes, Takes On ‘Swan Lake’
RssItem.Description: After a decade of waiting in the last line onstage, Ms. Teuscher is a soloist with American Ballet Theater and will make her New York debut this month.

RssItem.Title: #SpeakingInDance: Learning Dance From Photographs: David Gordon’s Muybridge Solo
RssItem.Description: Our latest installment in the Instagram series #SpeakingInDance features Valda Setterfield in David Gordon's "Live Archiveography."

RssItem.Title: 5 Must-See Shows if You’re in New York This Month
RssItem.Description: June brings a comedy for those who prefer to be weirded-out; a show for theatergoers with itchy feet; and Kevin Spacey in the role of Clarence Darrow.

RssItem.Title: Best of Late Night: ‘Covfefe’ Proves Trump ‘Really Does Have the Best Words,’ Samantha Bee Says
RssItem.Description: “And he spelled it right: v before e, except after z,” the “Full Frontal” host said Wednesday.

RssItem.Description: The comic tries his hand at writing and directing a feature film, producing a sweet, humorous drama about loss.

RssItem.Description: Otis Mass’s documentary portrait of a Manhattan celebrity photographer reflects a talented but exasperating pro.

RssItem.Title: Review: ‘Radio Dreams’ Builds a Spiritual Home for Stateless Souls
RssItem.Description: A fictional San Francisco radio station provides a place for immigrants adrift to bond in the ether.

RssItem.Description: Patty Jenkins narrates a sequence featuring Gal Gadot and Chris Pine.

RssItem.Description: Taking on the role that made Pamela Anderson famous, an actress first takes a few whacks at some golf balls.

RssItem.Title: Lebanon Bans ‘Wonder Woman’ Because Its Star Is From Israel
RssItem.Description: Gal Gadot was singled out by protesters over her mandated service in the Israeli army and a 2014 Facebook post about the Gaza conflict.

RssItem.Title: The First Time: Alan Alda: The First Time I Was Stabbed in the Face
RssItem.Description: The actor and author recalls a time when clearer communication may have saved a lot of dismay.

RssItem.Description: The “Younger” actress talks about her love of masks, serums and anything shimmery.

RssItem.Description: “Twilight” is in the rearview mirror, but he stands by the series even as he’s celebrated at Cannes for his turn as an inept bad guy in “Good Time.”

RssItem.Title: ‘The Square’ Wins Top Prize at Cannes; Sofia Coppola Is Best Director
RssItem.Description: Directed by Ruben Ostlund, “The Square” was a surprise winner of the Palme d’Or. With “The Beguiled,” Ms. Coppola became the second woman in the festival’s history to win the directing prize.

RssItem.Title: Women-Only Screenings of ‘Wonder Woman’ Sell Out and Prompt Complaints
RssItem.Description: The Alamo Drafthouse will host several screenings of “Wonder Woman” for women only. The decision received both criticism and support online.

RssItem.Title: ‘Pirates of the Caribbean’ Sequel Tops Box Office as ‘Baywatch’ Flops
RssItem.Description: “Dead Men Tell No Tales,” the latest film in the “Pirates” franchise, overcame poor reviews. “Baywatch” continued a string of lackluster TV adaptations.

RssItem.Title: Critic's Notebook: Kirsten Dunst on Calling Her Own Shots
RssItem.Description: The Cannes veteran talks about movies, sexism, female rage and “The Beguiled,” the third film that she’s made with the director Sofia Coppola.

RssItem.Title: ‘Saturday Night Fever’ at 40: You Should Still Be Dancing
RssItem.Description: On its anniversary, the gritty John Travolta disco classic gets a director’s cut, with 15 extra minutes.

RssItem.Title: Waiting for the Credits to End? Movies Are Naming More Names
RssItem.Description: Complex special effects can mean several thousand crew members are listed at the end. But not all workers are there, and some wish the scrolls were even longer.

RssItem.Title: A Word With: Geoffrey Rush Loves to Play Rogues and Fools. A Genius, Too.
RssItem.Description: He talks about portraying historical figures like Einstein and his fresh turn as Barbossa in “Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales.”

RssItem.Title: On Set: ‘Dirty Dancing’: Where Kellerman’s Came to Life
RssItem.Description: The lake where Johnny lifted Baby may be gone, but the North Carolina and Virginia sites where the film was shot still offer plenty of nostalgia.
